items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

1. Position Management
	 
a. Position Elimination
	 
Academic Advising Specialist, 100% FTE, (7LANG0229C) in the Language Arts Department at San Jose City College effective 06/30/15.
	 
Senior Administrative Assistant, 100% FTE, (9ITSS0220C) in the ITSS Department at the District Office effective 06/30/15. 
	 
b. Position Establishment
	 
Executive Administrative Assistant, 100% FTE, (9ITSS0233C) in the ITSS Department at the District Office effective 07/01/15. - See attached job description.
	 
Executive Administrative Assistant, 100% FTE, (9IBCD0269C) at the Workforce Institute effective 07/01/15.
	 
Program Coordinator, 100% FTE, (7CNSS0219C) in the Language Arts Department at San Jose City College effective 07/01/15.
	 
Traffic & Campus Services Officer, 100% FTE, (9COPS0237C) in the Campus Police Department at the District Office effective 05/13/15.
	 
2. Employment
	 
a. New Hire
	 
Traffic & Campus Services Officer, 100% FTE, (9COPS0232C) in the Campus Police Department at the District Office effective 05/13/15.
	 
3. Change of Status
	 
a. Reclassification 
	 
Reclassification process per the CSEA CBA Chapter 363 Article 23.1 and Article 23.3 "Reclassification will become effective July 1 of the year following the reclassification request."
	 
b. Working Out of Class
	 
The employee is receiving additional pay as Financial Aid Specialist II, 100% FTE, (7FAOX0208C) at Range 89-D in the Financial Aid Office at San Jose City College effective 12/01/14 through 06/30/15.
	 
The employee is working out of class as Senior Division Administrative Assistant, 100% FTE, (8BUSA0214C) in the Business and Workforce Development Department at Evergreen Valley College effective 05/01/15 through 06/30/15.
	 
4. Separation
	 
Employee separation effective 05/08/15.
Employee separation effective 06/24/15.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions exceeding the current bid limit of $86,000 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts, although not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions for the period of March 10, 2015 through April 9, 2015 as noted in the attached documents.

items.item_details:
On September 10, 2014 and September 17, 2014, Bid Proposal #1015-14 - Custodial Supplies was advertised for Districtwide custodial supplies. The bid included "green" specifications developed in collaboration between the Custodial and Purchasing Departments. After analyzing the bids, the lowest priced vendors were asked to submit samples of their products and dispensers for evaluation and rating. Attached herewith are an affidavit of publication and a list of vendors who participated in the bid and the list of criteria for which the evaluation was based. 
	 
The recommendation is to award California Janitorial Supply, a small business enterprise, for the procurement of Districtwide custodial supplies. This is a one (1) year award, that may be renewed annually, for a total contract term not to exceed (3) years.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees award the contract of Bid Proposal #1015-14 - Custodial Supplies to California Janitorial Supply, a Small Business Enterprise (SBE).
items.item_text: Award of Contract for Bid Proposal #1015-14 - Custodial Supplies

items.item_details:
The 2014-15 budget signed by Governor Brown provided funding on a one-time basis to “create greater incentive for California Community Colleges to develop, enhance, retool, and expand quality career technical education offerings that build upon existing community college regional capacity to respond to regional labor market needs.”  Funds may be used for equipment, curriculum and professional development and “other related costs necessary to develop, enhance, retool, and expand quality career technical education offerings.”
	 
Evergreen Valley College will receive $153,609.  These are one-time funds that must be fully spent by March of 2016.  No matching funds are required.
	 
The legislation requires that funds target labor markets where the number of job openings exceeds the supply of candidates from community colleges and from other education and training providers. It also requires that funds be utilized to facilitate alignment of CTE programs across multiple colleges to better serve regional scale industries and labor markets. 
	 
Evergreen Valley College will commit its share of the Enhancement Funds in the following program areas:
Computer Information Technology (Cisco Academy, Cyber Security, Mobile APPS)
Healthcare Management 
Entrepreneurship
	 
The CTE Enhancement Fund is a significant indication of the Governor and the legislature’s interest in supporting the Career Technical Education mission and of their desire to build the system’s capacity to become important contributors to the regional economies that are essential to California’s long-term economic vitality. Students will benefit from the greater depth and diversity of offerings that comes from regional alignment. The Chancellor’s Office is proposing that the funds become an annual allocation with the purpose of helping to offset the high cost of CTE programs.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Career Technical Education Enhancement Fund grant sub-agreement between Evergreen Valley College/SJECCD and Cabrillo Community College District.
items.item_text: CTE Grant Sub-Agreement Between Evergreen Valley College/SJECCD and Cabrillo Community College District

items.item_details:
On September 10, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to Environmental Systems Inc. in the amount of $668,340 to provide construction services or products for Technology Center/Student Center Interior Finish Upgrades Project #31304-11 at the SJCC.
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions; District requested or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract, scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.
	 
Change Order No. 001 includes additional labor and materials for the installation of additional carpet tiles and ceiling tiles in locations that were not in the original scope of work (contract), and a credit for a reduction of new resilient flooring in both the Technology Center  and Student Services Center, as requested by the College.
	 
	 
Pueblo Construction submitted written pricing proposals for these changes (details in the attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                      $  668,340
Previously Approved Changes              $        0.00
Change Order No. 001                         -$    11,376
	 
Revised Contract Amount                     $  656,964
	 
The net change to Environmental Systems Inc. contract as a result of all changes issued is -$11,376 which, equates to -1.70% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 001. in the amount of -$11,376 to Pueblo Construction for the Technology Ctr./ Student Ctr. Interior Finish Upgrades Project 31304-11 at SJCC.
items.item_text: San Jose City College (SJCC) – Technology Ctr./Student Ctr. Interior Finish Upgrades Project #31304-11– Pueblo Construction, Change Order No. 001.
items.item_text_raw: 2. San Jose City College (SJCC) – Technology Ctr./Student Ctr. Interior Finish Upgrades Project #31304-11– Pueblo Construction, Change Order No. 001.

items.item_details:
The contract for the Technology Ctr. /Student Ctr. Interior Finish Upgrades project #31304-11 at San Jose City College included the installation of new carpet tiles, resilient flooring in specified locations and the replacement of damaged ceiling tiles.  The upgrades in whole made for a more efficient, cleaner and safer environment, which in turn minimizes cost for maintenance, cause for safety hazards and injuries.
	 
On September 10, 2014, the Board approved the Agreement for Pueblo Construction to perform the Work.  On November 3, 2014 construction activity began and on January 5, 2015, major construction activity was completed.  As of May 12, 2015 all construction work has been approved by the Architect of Record, all closeout documents have been received, and all Change Orders have been approved. 
	 
Once approved, this Notice of Completion (NOC) will be filed with the County of Santa Clara, Office of the Recorder.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Notice of Completion (NOC) of the contract by Pueblo Construction for the SJCC Technology Ctr. /Student Ctr. Interior Finish Upgrades Project #31304-11 upgrades of carpet, resilient flooring and ceiling tiles in the Technology Ctr. and Student Ctr., buildings of San Jose City College Campus.

items.item_text_raw: 3. San Jose City College (SJCC) Technology Ctr. /Student Ctr. Interior Finish Upgrades Project #31304-11 – Pueblo Construction - Notice of Completion (NOC)

items.item_details:
The scope of the Campus Site Improvements: Site Lighting project includes enhancements to the exterior lighting along main pedestrian pathways to provide improved safety and security.  
	 
The project was posted on the District’s purchasing website and advertised in local papers on April 1, 2015 and April 8, 2015. It was published at local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to over 90 contractors including small minority and woman-owned firms.  On April 23, 2015
construction bids were received as follows:
	 
            DV Electric                                          $23,900.00
            AMP Electric                                       $29,456.00
            Sanpri Electric                                     $35,500.00
	 
DV Electric from San Jose, California was determined to be the lowest responsive and responsible bidder in the amount of $23,900.00. It was noted when Bids were opened that DV Electric’s Bid was missing an acknowledgement of receipt for Amendment #1, however DV submitted the Acknowledgement immediately after Bid opening, and cured the requirement.
	 
On April 24, 2015, the District received a bid protest from the number 3 bidder, Sanpri Electric because the bid packet submitted by DV Electric did not include acknowledgement of Amendment #1. After consulting with legal counsel, the District has determined that DV’s failure to include acknowledgement of Amendment #1, is a non-material omission and a minor irregularity which was readily cured and can be waived by the District. (See attached letter to Sanpri.)
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board waive the minor irregularity in DV Electric’s bid response, deny the bid protest submitted by Sanpri Electric, Inc., and authorize award of a contract in the amount of $23,900.00 to DV Electric for G2010.0124 SJCC Campus Site Lighting.
items.item_text: San Jose City Community College (SJCC) Campus Site Improvement Project #31116-04, Site Lighting – DV Electric Agreement
items.item_text_raw: 5. San Jose City Community College (SJCC) Campus Site Improvement Project #31116-04, Site Lighting – DV Electric Agreement

items.item_details:
This agenda item is for the purchase of network switches and installation services at San Jose City College. This project is to replace the network switches throughout SJCC in order to install a new converged, high-performance, high-capacity data network for computer, wireless, voice, video and device communications for all students, staff, faculty, administrators and guests. The project timeline is to deploy the network switches first in the core network and then building by building between June 1 and August 21, 2015 (provided no unforeseen delays - the timeline is based on Dasher Discovery Services). The deployment schedule will seek to minimize network disruptions to classrooms, labs and offices with an expectation that some minor outages will be scheduled in advance. The completion of the project will require installing additional electrical circuits in some of the Telecommunication Rooms and purchasing UPS's for the network switches (future purchase). In addition, a total of 334 Wireless Access Points will be installed during this timeline and connected to the new network switches per a separate Board Agenda item.
	 
This project is a major deliverable of Bond Project #31702 to upgrade the IT and Technology Equipment at SJCC. The ICA and network switch purchase is based on RFP # G2010.0099 and pursuant to the Master Agreement with Dasher Technologies approved by the board on 8/26/14 (Measure G-2010 Bond Program).
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the purchase of network switches and Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) with Dasher Technologies to configure and deploy at San Jose City College for a total cost of $1,686,529.43.
items.item_text: Measure G 2010 Bond Program: Network Switch Upgrade at San Jose City College
items.item_text_raw: 6. Measure G 2010 Bond Program: Network Switch Upgrade at San Jose City College

items.item_details:
This Phase 2 Wireless Network Installation scope is for the purchase of 319 Wireless Access Points (WAPs) and installation of 334 WAPs (the installation service includes 15 WAPs from a previous order) to be used by students, staff, faculty, administrators and guests at SJCC. These WAPs will be incorporated into a new enterprise wireless system that is used at SJCC and district wide. The project timeline is to deploy the WAPs throughout SJCC between June 1 and August 21, 2015 (provided no unforeseen delays - the timeline is based on Dasher Discovery Services). The deployment schedule will seek to minimize disruptions to classrooms, labs and offices with an expectation that some minor interruptions will be scheduled in advance. 
	 
The third and final phase of the wireless network installation at SJCC will include about 100 additional WAPs and installation services to provide coverage for outdoor spaces (future Board Agenda). 
	 
This project is a major deliverable of Bond Project #31702 to upgrade the IT and Technology Equipment at SJCC. The ICA and WAP purchase is based on RFP # G2010.0099 and pursuant to the Master Agreement with Dasher Technologies approved by the board on 8/26/14 (Measure G-2010 Bond Program).
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the purchase of Wireless Access Points and Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) with Dasher Technologies to configure and deploy at San Jose City College for a total cost of $423,438.91
items.item_text: Measure G Bond Program: Phase 2 Wireless Network Installation at San Jose City College
items.item_text_raw: 7. Measure G Bond Program: Phase 2 Wireless Network Installation at San Jose City College

items.item_details:
On November 11, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to C. Overaa & Company in the amount of $11,347,704 to provide construction services for the Automotive Technology Building Project at Evergreen Valley College.   
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District requested design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 002 is for the temporary generator and fuel costs associated with providing power for the project prior to permanent power hookup, revisions to the hydronic piping into the building to avoid structural grade beams, and revised plumbing, mechanical and HVAC equipment which will allow the project to attain additional LEED points.       
	 
C. Overaa & Company submitted written pricing proposals for these changes (details in the Agenda attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions, and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                    $11,347,704
Previously Approved Changes            $     277,476
Change Order No. 002                        $       97,529
Revised Contract Amount                    $11,722,709
	 
The net change to C. Overaa & Company's contract as a result of all changes issued is $375,005, which equates to 3.30% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 002 in the amount of $97,529 to C. Overaa & Company for the Automotive Technology Building Project at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Measure G – 2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Automotive Technology Building, Project #32111 - C. Overaa & Company Change Order No. 002
items.item_text_raw: 8. Measure G – 2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Automotive Technology Building, Project #32111 - C. Overaa & Company Change Order No. 002

items.item_details:
On August 26, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved an Agreement to Blach Construction Company in the amount of $41,639,729 to provide construction services for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District request design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 006 includes Work of: adding curbs at the second floor lab plumbing room, mechanical system modifications, increase thickness exterior metal panels, additional intumescent fireproofing, exterior flashing and waterproofing upgrades, and a credit for excess dry erase boards.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.  
	 
Original Contract Amount                     $41,639,729.00
Previous Approved Changes                $     383,373.04
Change Order No. 006                         $       39,685.60 
Total Contract and Changes                $42,062,787.64
	 
The net change to Blach Construction Company’s contract as a result of all changes issued is $423,058.64 which equates to 1.02% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from the project contingency established in the project budget.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 006 in the amount of $39,685.60 to Blach Construction Company for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College South Campus Development Project #32107 – Blach Construction Company Change Order No. 006
items.item_text_raw: 9. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College South Campus Development Project #32107 – Blach Construction Company Change Order No. 006

items.item_details:
The contract for the Soccer Field Bleacher Project #210-01 at Evergreen Valley College was necessary to provide bleacher seating for the Evergreen Valley Soccer Field.
                                                                                               
On December 10, 2013, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to Guerra Construction Group to perform the work.  On December 11, 2013, construction activity began and on December 31, 2014, major construction activity was completed.  As of December 31, 2014, all construction work has been approved by the Architect of Record, all closeout documents have been received, and all Change Orders have been approved.
	 
Once approved, this NOC will be filed with the County of Santa Clara, Office of the Recorder.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the NOC of the contract by Guerra Construction Group, EVC College Soccer Field Phase 1 Bleacher Project #210-01 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
The Education Code designates the third full week in May as Classified School Employee Week.  Section 88270 states “All community colleges shall annually observe that week in recognition of classified school employees and the contributions they make to the educational community.”
	 
The attached resolution recognizes the important contributions made by classified employees of the San Jose/Evergreen Community College District and extends the celebration to the full month of May 2015.  
	 
The District Office will hold a Service Award Ceremony and each college will organize at least one event.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 051215-2 in support of Classified School Employee Appreciation Month

items.item_details:
An Election was held in the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District (the “District”) on November 2, 2004 for the issuance and sale of general obligation bonds of the District for various purposes in the maximum principal amount of $185,000,000 (the “2004 Authorization”).  Pursuant to the 2004 Authorization, the District has previously caused the issuance of its (i) General Obligation Bonds, Election of 2004, Series A, in the aggregate principal amount of $55,391,474 (the “2004 Series A Bonds”) and (ii) General Obligation Bonds, Election of 2004, Series B, in the aggregate principal amount of $97,999,945.55 (the “2004 Series B Bonds”).  The District has previously refunded a portion of the 2004 Series A Bonds through the issuance of its 2014 General Obligation Refunding Bonds, Series A.  
	 
The District now desires to refinance all or a portion of the remaining outstanding 2004 Series A Bonds and a portion of the outstanding 2004 Series B Bonds (so refunded, the “Refunding Bonds”) through the issuance of general obligation refunding bonds (the “Refunding Bonds”) in an aggregate principal amount not-to-exceed $100,000,000.  All benefits from the refunding will be delivered to the property owners in the District.  The final maturity of the Refunding Bonds will not be later than the maturity dates of the Refunded Bonds.
	 
(a)        Resolution.  This Resolution authorizes the issuance of the Refunding Bonds, in one or more series of federally taxable or federally tax-exempt bonds, authorizes the issuance of the Refunding Bonds, specifies the basic terms, parameters and forms of the Refunding Bonds, and approves the form of Purchase Contract, Continuing Disclosure Certificate, Escrow Agreement and Preliminary Official Statement described below.  In particular, Section 1 of the Resolution establishes the maximum aggregate principal amount of the Refunding Bonds to be issued ($100,000,000).  Section 4 of the Resolution states the maximum underwriting discount (0.4%) with respect to the Refunding Bonds, and authorizes the Refunding Bonds to be sold at a negotiated sale to Piper Jaffray & Co. (the “Underwriter”).  The Resolution authorizes the issuance of current interest bonds only.
	 
(b)        Form of Purchase Contract.  Pursuant to the Purchase Contract, the Underwriter will agree to buy the Refunding Bonds from the District.  All of the conditions of closing the transaction are set forth in this document, including the documentation to be provided at the closing by various parties.  Upon the pricing of the Refunding Bonds, the final execution copy of the Purchase Contract will be prepared following this form.
	 
(c)           Form of Preliminary Official Statement.  The Preliminary Official Statement (the “POS”) is the offering document describing the Refunding Bonds which may be distributed to prospective purchasers of the Refunding Bonds.  The POS discloses information with respect to, among other things, (i) the proposed uses of proceeds of the Refunding Bonds, (ii) the terms of the Refunding Bonds (interest rate, transfer terms, etc.), (iii) the bond insurance policy for the Refunding Bonds, if any, (iv) the security for repayment of the Refunding Bonds (the ad valorem property tax levy), (v) information with respect to the District’s tax base (upon which such ad valorem property taxes may be levied), (vi) District financial and operating data, (vii) continuing disclosure with respect to the Refunding Bonds and the District, and (viii) absence of litigation and other miscellaneous matters expected to be of interest to prospective purchasers of the Refunding Bonds.  Following the pricing of the Refunding Bonds, a final Official Statement for the Refunding Bonds will be prepared, substantially in the form of the POS.
	 
(d)          Form of the Continuing Disclosure Certificate.  The form of the Continuing Disclosure Certificate can be found in APPENDIX C to the POS.  Effective July 3, 1995, all underwriters of municipal bonds, are obligated to procure from a bond issuer a covenant that such public agency will annually file “material financial information and operating data with respect to the District” through the web-based Electronic Municipal Market Access (“EMMA”) system maintained by the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board (which is the federal agency that regulates “broker-dealers,” including investment bank firms that underwrite municipal obligation issuance).  This requirement is expected to be satisfied by the filing of the District’s audited financial statements and other operating information about the District, in the same manner the District has filed in connection with prior bond issuances.  The purpose of the law is to provide investors in the Refunding Bonds with current information regarding the District.  Similar laws have governed the corporate debt market for many years. 
	 
(e)          Escrow Agreement.  Pursuant to the Escrow Agreement, proceeds from the sale of the Refunding Bonds in an amount sufficient to redeem the Refunded Bonds will be deposited in an escrow fund (the “Escrow Fund”) held by U.S. Bank National Association (acting as “Escrow Agent”).  The monies in the Escrow Fund will be used by the Escrow Agent to refund all or a portion of the Prior Bonds on the respective first available redemption dates following the closing of the Refunding Bonds (September 1, 2015 for the 2004 Series A Bonds, and September 1, 2018 for the 2004 Series B Bonds).  As a result of the deposit and application of funds so provided in the Escrow Agreement, the Refunded Bonds will be defeased and the obligation of Santa Clara County to levy ad valorem property taxes for payment of the Refunded Bonds will cease.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT
	 
There is no fiscal impact to the General Fund resulting from the issuance of the Refunding Bonds.  
	 
RECOMMENDATION
	 
Staff recommends approval of Resolution No. 051215-3 RESOLUTION AUTHORIZING THE ISSUANCE OF THE SAN JOSE-EVERGREEN COMMUNITY COLLEGE DISTRICT (SANTA CLARA COUNTY, CALIFORNIA) 2015 GENERAL OBLIGATION REFUNDING BONDS.

items.item_details: On April 30, 2015, President Obama issued a Presidential Proclamation proclaiming May 2015 as Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month. In support of this proclamation and in celebration of the achievements of Asian American and Pacific Islander faculty, administrators, staff and students, Evergreen Valley College and San Jose City College organized events in which Asian American and Pacific Islander culture was celebrated. It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approves Resolution No. 051215-4 in support of May 2015 as Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month.

The District and California School Employees Association Chapter 363 have completed negotiations for 2014-2015. The California School Employees Association ratified the tentative agreements for Articles 6, 8, 13, 15, and 23.
	 
Article 6 Salary – The District shall provide a 5% increase to be applied to the CSEA salary schedule retroactive to July 1, 2014.  Current employees are eligible for retroactive pay.
	 
Article 6.6 & 6.6.2 – Temporary or Permanent Reassignment of a Unit Member to a Position with a Higher Salary Range
	 
Article 8.3 – District Initiated Work Schedule Change Short-Term Adjustment & Article 8.3.2 Long-Term Adjustment
	 
Article 8.8 – Unit Member Initiated Altered Work Schedule Change
	 
Article 13.1.4 – General Provisions
	 
Article 15.2.1 – Internal Professional Development Opportunities
	 
Article 23.1 - Reclassification

items.item_details:
As part of the accountability measures for the Measure G-2004 Bond Program, the management team for the program has put into place a formal process for managing, tracking and presenting to the Board of Trustees all revisions to the Measure G-2004 individual project names, scopes and budgets.  This process adheres to the accountability standards outlined by Proposition 39 and provides transparency in the evolution of the project list.
	 
This Bond List Revision request includes allocation of interest earnings.
	 
Please refer to the attached Bond List Revision Approval Request report and the Summary of Current Changes report for details on the project revision included on the G-2004 Bond List Revision dated May 12, 2015.
	 
This Bond List Revision has been approved by the San Jose City College and Evergreen Valley College Vice Presidents of Administrative Services and the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees review and approve the revisions to the Measure G - 2004 bond list, as presented.
items.item_text: Measure G-2004 Bond Program: Bond List Revision
items.item_text_raw: 6. Measure G-2004 Bond Program: Bond List Revision

items.item_details:
As part of the accountability measures for the Measure G-2010 Bond Program, the management team for the program has put into place a formal process for managing, tracking and presenting to the Board of Trustees all revisions to the Measure G-2010 individual project names, scopes and budgets.  This process adheres to the accountability standards outlined by Proposition 39 and provides transparency in the evolution of the project list.
	 
Bond List Revision No. 13 includes the following revisions: interest earnings allocations, the recognition of project savings, the creation of two projects at San Jose City College, the creation of one new District Wide project in support of Proposition 39:  Clean Energy initiatives, the realignment of budget at Evergreen Valley College as well as a distribution of the excess Program Contingency.  
	 
At the start of the bond program, the Program Contingency account was set at 3% of the program. As projects are completed, risk is reduced, and the contingency percentage goes up.  This budget move represents the distribution of contingency above the 3%.  San Jose City College has elected to place its distribution into its campus contingency account where the college is currently holding funds, awaiting the outcome of the updated Educational & Facilities Master Plan.  Evergreen Valley College elected to place its contingency distribution into 32107 South Campus Development and 32702 IT and Technology Equipment.  The District placed its distribution into 39310 MDF Relocation as well as providing a contribution to 32116 Central Green for the inclusion of conduit and infrastructure in that project which will support the MDF Relocation.  The balance of the District distribution went to its contingency account.
	 
Please refer to the attached Bond List Revision Approval Request report and the Summary of Current Changes report for details on each project revision included on the G-2010 Bond List Revision No. 13 dated May 12, 2015.
	 
These Bond List Revisions have been approved by the San Jose City College and Evergreen Valley College Vice Presidents of Administrative Services and the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees review and approve the revisions to the Measure G - 2010 bond list, as presented.

items.item_details:
To comply with Governmental Accounting Standards Board (GASB) Statements 43 and 45, the San Jose Evergreen Community College District developed and implemented a Substantive Plan focused on the delivery and funding of health and welfare benefits for eligible retirees and their spouses.
	 
Taxable Other Post Employment Benefits (OPEB) bonds were issued on May 14, 2009, in the amount of $46,775,000 to fund this liability and the funds were deposited into an OPEB Irrevocable Trust.  Issuing the bonds ensured that the District complied with GASB Statements 43 and 45; allowed the District to determine how the benefit costs and long-term liability would be funded over time; and provided the District with initial savings to the Unrestricted General Fund.  It is to be noted that the District incorporated capitalized interest to satisfy the debt service for the first two years; thereby, avoiding any OPEB-related debt service payments from District funds in the first two years.
	 
On March 13, 2012, the Board of Trustees adopted Resolution 031312-2 authorizing the re-marketing of the bonds to further reduce the exposure to the Unrestricted General Fund and to lock in a fixed rate for 15 years.  It is projected that in FY 2014-2015 the Unrestricted General Fund will contribute $1,953,150 toward the $2,477,542 debt-service obligation, which remains less than the projected cost of benefits totaling $3,522,299.
	 
The actuarial study by Nyhart-Epler dated June 30, 2013, determined that the long-term liability associated with these benefit commitments was $40,148,891 with net assets of $47,450,296, which means that the liability was over-funded as of June 30, 2013, by $7,301,405 or a funded ratio of 118%.  The District is currently engaged in updating the actuarial study with an effective date of June 30, 2015.
	 
The Retirement Board of Authority (RBOA) oversees and implements the OPEB Trust, which has a targeted net investment rate of return of 7.88% and possesses net assets of $49,322,390.54 as of March 31, 2015.
	 
Attached for reference is the actuarial report dated June 30, 2013; the performance letter dated April 8, 2015, from Benefit Trust; and the presentation from the RBOA.

items.item_details:
This information item will provide a status update on the Measure G-2004 & Measure G-2010 bond programs and highlight several of the active projects as well as provide a review of Gilbane's performance through year four (FY2014/15) and information relating to the renewal of Gilbane's agreement for year five (FY2015/16). 
	 
The District successfully passed Measure G-2010 on November 2, 2010.  On January 25, 2011 a facilities and bonds study session served as an opportunity to share a framework for success for Measure G-2010.  Included in this framework was the recommendation that the District utilize a program and construction management firm to provide program and construction management services to the colleges and District to support implementation of various construction and deferred maintenance projects. In keeping with the District's desire to promote accountability, efficiency and cost effectiveness, the District went through a formal Request for Qualifications process to seek the services of a Program and Construction Management firm to provide system-wide coordination and oversight of all capital improvement work performed under the Measure G-2010 bond program.  Gilbane Building Company was selected through this process.
	 
Since the initial one-year contract with Gilbane awarded by the Board on May 10, 2011, policies and procedures for operating under the Bond have been implemented, overall program and detailed project scheduling has been established and maintained, accounting and purchasing procedures have been put in place and numerous projects have commenced design and are going into construction on the campuses and for the District. Each contract was for time and materials only at a not-to-exceed amount, with the fourth year (FY2014/15) value of $5,724,420.  The agreement has the option to renew annually through 2018.  The proposed contract amount for the fifth year (FY2015/16) is valued at $5,297,131.
	 
As for the Measure G-2004 bond program, the FY2014/15 contract is $980,785 and the proposed FY2015/16 contract is $1,306,030.
	 
The Board is being asked to review this information on May 12, 2015 and then take action on a year five (FY2015/16) contract renewal for the Measure G-2010 bond program and a contract for FY2015/16 for the Measure G-2004 bond program at the June 19, 2015 Board of Trustees meeting.

items.item_details:
Pursuant to Government Code Section 3547, the San Jose/Evergreen Federation of Teachers, AFT 6157 presents their Contract Proposal with the San Jose/Evergreen Community College District for 2015-2016.  The San Jose/Evergreen Federation of Teachers AFT 6157 requests that issues in the following articles be negotiated for 2015-2016.
	 
2015 Contract Sunshine Proposal
AFT 6157 Opening Proposal May 12, 2015
	 
	The following represents the opening proposal from the San José/Evergreen Federation of Teachers AFT 6157 (Union) to the District. The Union reserves the right to add, amend, delete or change any of these proposals: 8 Articles of Choice and Articles 8, 9, 17, and 18.
	 
Article 4 Additional Faculty Member Rights
	               Adjunct Centers
	 
Article 5 AFT 6157 Rights/New Faculty Orientation
	               PRC Reassigned Time
	 
Article 8 Full-Time Salary, Hire Dates and Seniority Number
	               Equitable Compensation Adjustments and other Increases for Full time Faculty
	               Clarify Article 8.5 Non-Master’s Class Placement
	 
Article 9 Adjunct Faculty and Substitutes
	               Equitable Compensation Adjustments and other Increases for Adjunct Faculty
	               Pay for Committee Work
	               Increase Pay for Office Hours
	               Adjunct Faculty Parity/Equity Changes
	               Health Benefits-Make Improvements including EAP
	               SDI- Side Letter
	               Ancillary Activities
	 
Article 10 Professional Recognition
	              Add fund for Staff Development for Full-time and Adjunct Faculty
	 
Article 11 Working Days/Calendars
	             Calendar for 2017-2018
	             Calendar 2015-2016 and 2016-2017- Add No Saturday Classes
	             Non-Instructional Workload-Voluntary 11 Month Contract
	 
Article 12 Workload, Class Size, Class Cancellation
	               Eliminate Cumulative Load
	               Add New Faculty FSA’s for Increased Lab Load
	 
Article 13 Leaves of Absence
	               FMLA Changes
	               AB 1606
	               Catastrophic Leave-Language Clean up -1X Year donation
	              
Article 15 Overload
	               Counseling Offering of Overload –Develop Contract Language 
	                    
Article 17 Benefits
	Remove Medical Benefit Cap
	 
Article 18 Retirement
	               Remove Medical Benefit Cap
	               Add EAP Plan for Bridge Program
	 
New Article-Safety
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
	Present the District's contract proposal for 2015-2016, and announcement of a public hearing to be conducted at the May 26, 2015 June 9, 2015, Board meeting.

items.item_details:
Per its adopted governing principles, the Board of Trustees will evaluate its performance at the end of each meeting.
	 
The Board will consider two items in discussing its evaluation:
	 
1.To ascertain the effectiveness of the meeting in attaining the advancement of the Board's Global Ends Policy.
	 
2.To ascertain the degree to which Trustees adhered to the Board adopted Governance Principle: Trustees Code of Conduct.
